description: Rufus Gifford, former US Ambassador to Denmark, shares his thoughts on how Europe is reacting to President Trump's renewed calls to take over Greenland following the US Venezuela move this past weekend. Gifford states trust has been broken between Denmark & the United States, and that it is heartbreaking to hear the rhetoric from the President and his administration. He speaks with Joe Mathieu and Tyler Kendall on the late edition of Bloomberg's "Balance of Power."  (Source: Bloomberg)
title: Greenland on Alert After US Venezuela Move

author: Dana Hull, Rick Clough
description: A US lawmaker is preparing legislation to require that new motor vehicles be equipped with manual door releases, a move to address safety concerns with the type of electrically powered handles popularized by Tesla Inc.
title: US Lawmaker Readies Bill Requiring Manual Door Handles in Cars

author: Andreina Itriago
description: Venezuelan security forces have detained Johan Benlolo Jiménez, a hairstylist at a popular salon in Miami, among at least a few US citizens in their custody, according to people familiar with the situation.
title: Miami Hairstylist Among US Citizens Detained in Venezuela

description:
On today's episode of Bloomberg Businessweek Daily, Carol Massar and Tim Stenovec discuss the Supreme Court setting Friday for opinions, with a possible decision about President Trump's tariff regime on deck given the court's expedited handling of the case. Bloomberg's Greg Stohr joins the show to discuss. Plus, Bloomberg International Economics & Policy Correspondent Michael McKee looks ahead to Friday's December Payrolls report. Also, Bloomberg Tech Co-Host Caroline Hyde sits down with Qualcomm President & CEO Cristiano Amon from CES in Las Vegas about the future of robotics and AI. Mandeep Singh of Bloomberg Intelligence also weighs in on 
Nvidia and Siemens' AI industrial partnership, and Christina Lee of Oaktree Capital Management 
discusses enthusiasm in private equity and M&A. (Source: Bloomberg)
title: Qualcomm CEO Says AI 'Not a Bubble' | Bloomberg Businessweek Daily 01/06/2026

author: Erik Larson
description: The seizure of Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro and his wife by US special forces to face narco-terrorism charges raises a range of legal questions, including whether their capture during a late-night raid violated US or international law.
title: Did Maduro’s Seizure Violate US and International Law?

description: Patrullajes armados y detenciones sostienen el control en Caracas.
title: El gobierno del miedo persiste en Venezuela tras la captura de Maduro: Fotos

author: Jennifer A Dlouhy, Courtney Subramanian
description: US President Donald Trump is set to meet with energy executives at the White House within the next week as he seeks to enlist Western companies in rebuilding Venezuela’s oil industry.
title: Trump to Meet Oil Bosses to Push for Venezuela Output Revival

author: Kate Sullivan, Sara Sjolin
description: President Donald Trump won’t rule out the use of military force to acquire Greenland, the White House said, ramping up tension with fellow NATO member Denmark over a dispute that’s surged back into public view following the ouster of Venezuelan strongman Nicolas Maduro.
title: Trump Won’t Rule Out Military Force to Acquire Greenland

author: Ted Mann
description: The president warns congressional GOP about  midterm consequences.
title: Trump’s Message to Republicans: Just Don’t Lose the Midterms

author: K Oanh Ha, Naomi Ng, Eleanor Harrison-Dengate, Rachael Lewis-Krisky
description: On today’s Big Take Asia podcast, what Trump’s move on Venezuela means for China’s place in Latin America – and the risk to Taiwan.
title: Does Venezuela Hand China a Blueprint for Taiwan?

description: Cristiano Amon, Qualcomm President & CEO speaks with Caroline Hyde from CES in Las Vegas about the future for Qualcomm in the AI era. He shares his thoughts on robotics and autonomous driving cars. (Source: Bloomberg)
title: Amon: AI Not a Bubble for Qualcomm

description: Michael McKee, Bloomberg International Economics & Policy Correspondent speaks with Carol Massar and Tim Stenovec about how legal ruling against tariffs would undercut Trump's economic policy. (Source: Bloomberg)
title: Court Deliberating Trump's 'Liberation Day' Tariffs

author: Patricia Laya, Katherine Pennacchio
description: Venezuela’s acting President Delcy Rodríguez said no foreign power was governing the country, pushing back against suggestions that the US had assumed control.
title: Venezuela’s Rodríguez Says No Foreign Power Governs Nation

description: Bloomberg News Supreme Court reporter Greg Stohr says that the high court could hand down a decision on Trump's tariff authority on Friday, but clarified that its not a guarantee. The tariff case is just one of many of decisions the Supreme Court has yet to hand down.  (Source: Bloomberg)
title: Supreme Court Sets Friday For Opinions As US Waits for Tariff Decision

author: Chris Dolmetsch
description: Ousted Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro added Bruce Fein, a former top Justice Department lawyer during the Reagan administration, to his legal team, according to a court filing Tuesday.
title: Venezuela’s Maduro Adds Ex-Reagan Era DOJ Lawyer to Legal Team

author: Danielle Bochove
description: As European leaders seek to persuade President Donald Trump that Greenland’s security is best defended by NATO, broader concerns persist about US expansionism. Bloomberg News spoke with Bob Rae, Canada’s ambassador to the United Nations from 2020 to 2025. A lawyer by training, Rae was previously the premier of Ontario and interim leader of the Liberal Party of Canada.
title: Trump’s Greenland Threats Call for Firm Response From Allies, Canada’s Rae Says

description: On the early edition of Balance of Power, Bloomberg Washington Correspondents Joe Mathieu and Tyler Kendall discuss President Donald Trump's foreign policy plans. On today's show, former White House National Security Advisor John Bolton, Stonecourt Capital Partner Rick Davis, Harvard Kennedy School's Ash Center Visiting Democracy Fellow Jeanne Sheehan Zaino, Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang and Siemens President and CEO Roland Busch. (Source: Bloomberg)
title: Rubio Tapped for Venezuela Overhaul | Balance of Power: Early Edition 1/06/2026

author: Monique Vanek
description: South African President Cyril Ramaphosa appointed Lekgoa Mothibi as the nation’s new chief prosecutor, elevating him to a pivotal role in the fight against entrenched graft and organized crime.
title: Ramaphosa Names New South Africa Chief Prosecutor to Fight Graft

description: Former National Security Advisor John Bolton says President Donald Trump didn't change the regime in Venezuela. He talks about the future of the country, how the US can run it, and its impact on the oil industry on "Balance of Power." (Source: Bloomberg)
title: Trump Didn't Change Regime in Venezuela, Bolton Says

description: Former National Security Advisor John Bolton says there's really been no regime change in Venezuela, but President Donald Trump was right to remove Nicolás Maduro as president. He's worried "we've removed the face of the regime, but not the regime itself." (Source: Bloomberg)
title: There's Been No Regime Change in Venezuela, Bolton Says

author: Samy Adghirni, Andrea Palasciano, Alex Wickham, Donato Paolo Mancini
description: President Donald Trump’s administration and Ukraine’s allies converged toward an agreement to offer security guarantees long sought by Kyiv during a Tuesday meeting of the so-called coalition of the willing.
title: European Leaders Hail US Backstop to Protect Postwar Ukraine

description: "Bloomberg Crypto" covers the people, transactions, and technology shaping the world of decentralized finance. Today's guests: Ripple President Monica Long and Former CFTC Director Enforcement Ian McGinley. (Source: Bloomberg)
title: Maduro Prediction Market Bets, Ripple Looks Beyond XRP | Bloomberg Crypto 1/6/2026

description: The capture of Maduro shows how openly breaking the law abroad mirrors Trump’s assault on constitutional limits at home, Bloomberg Opinion columnist Noah Feldman explains. (Source: Bloomberg)
title: Trump’s Venezuela Raid Was Illegal

author: Will Standring
description: Business groups representing UK pubs and hotels held talks on Tuesday with Treasury officials as they push for further tax discounts to alleviate the burden of changes made by Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves in her budget in November.
title: UK Pubs Pitch Tax Discount to Treasury Amid Budget Concerns

description:
Venezuela’s government is reasserting itself after the capture of Nicolás Maduro, swearing in Delcy Rodríguez as acting president and flashing warning signs that a new wave of repression has begun.
As the government continued to churn inside the presidential palace Miraflores, Venezuela’s military counterintelligence officials have been patrolling the streets of Caracas, according to at least two witnesses. At least seven journalists and members of the press were detained on Monday morning and early afternoon, most of them at the National Assembly and its surroundings, according to the national press workers syndicate. Jimena Zuniga, Bloomberg News Latin America Geoeconomics Analyst joins to discuss. (Source: Bloomberg)
title: Venezuela Regroups With New Leader, Old Repression Tactics

author: Alicia Diaz, Erik Wasson
description: President Donald Trump implored Republicans to turn around their political fortunes ahead of November’s midterm elections, warning that if Democrats retake control of Congress, he would be impeached for a third time.
title: Trump Warns He’ll Be Impeached If Republicans Lose Midterms

author: Jen Judson
description: Lockheed Martin Corp. struck a deal with the Pentagon that’s meant to triple production of its Patriot air-defense missile, part of a broader US push to speed up weapons output and meet global demand for a highly sought-after weapons system.
title: Lockheed Strikes Deal to Triple Output of Patriot Missiles

author: Matthew Malinowski
description: Chile’s President-elect José Antonio Kast will nominate Jorge Quiroz as finance minister, local newspaper Diario Financiero reported on Tuesday.
title: Chile’s Kast Taps Jorge Quiroz as Finance Chief, Newspaper Says

author: Alicia A. Caldwell
description: The Department of Homeland Security is spending about $85,000 on parkas for what it calls an “urgent enforcement mission” in Minnesota, where federal agents have fanned out for a monthlong immigration crackdown in the middle of winter.
title: ICE Orders $85,000 of Parkas in Urgent Minnesota Winter Crackdown

author: Greg Stohr
description: The US Supreme Court scheduled Friday as an opinion day, indicating that date will be the first chance for a ruling on President Donald Trump’s global tariffs.
title: Supreme Court Sets Friday for Opinions With Tariffs Pending

description: President Donald Trump says the US needs to control Greenland for national security purposes. “Greenland is covered with Russian and Chinese ships all over the place. We need Greenland, from the standpoint of national security, and Denmark is not going to be able to do it, I can tell you.” He spoke to reporters on Jan. 4 on Air Force One. (Source: Bloomberg)
title: Trump Says US Needs to Control Greenland

author: Erik Wasson
description: Republican Representative Doug LaMalfa has died, further shrinking the narrow GOP House majority, according to party leaders.
title: Republican Congressman LaMalfa Dies, Cutting House Majority

author: Andrea Palasciano, Donato Paolo Mancini
description: President Donald Trump’s administration will agree to support Ukraine in the event of a future Russian attack, according to a draft statement being negotiated by Kyiv’s top allies.
title: US to Promise Ukraine Support to Counter New Russian Attacks

author: Julian Lee, Sherry Su
description: The value of Moscow’s crude shipments slumps to the lowest since the Ukraine invasion
title: Russian Oil Flows and Prices Plunge to Hammer Putin’s War Chest

author: Greg Ryan, Georgia Hall
description: Rhode Island Governor Dan McKee is warming to the idea of a tax on the wealthy as one way to bolster the state’s resources after a particularly turbulent year for its economy.
title: Rhode Island Eyes Tax on Rich to Counter Trump Policies

author: Sara Sjolin
description: European leaders closed ranks behind Denmark as President Donald Trump amplified threats to seize Greenland, warning that existing borders were non-negotiable and arguing Arctic security must be achieved through NATO.
title: European Leaders Urge Trump to Respect Greenland’s Borders

author: Colum Murphy, Yujing Liu
description: Ireland’s Premier Micheal Martin said his discussions with top Chinese leaders during his official visit revealed a desire for a broader framework to manage trade ties between the Asian nation and the European Union.
title: Irish PM Sees Appetite in China for Trade Framework With EU

author: Soo-Hyang Choi, Yoshiaki Nohara
description: Hours after President Xi Jinping posed for selfies with South Korea’s Lee Jae Myung in Beijing, China sent a very different message to Japan, escalating their dispute by imposing export controls.
title: China Courts South Korea as It Pressures Japan Over Taiwan

author: Gonzalo Soto
description: President Claudia Sheinbaum will find it harder now to dismiss threats from her country’s belligerent neighbor to the north.
title: Trump’s Aggressive New Doctrine Looms Large Over Mexico

author: Arsalan Shahla
description: Iran’s government ordered an investigation into clashes between protesters and riot police at a hospital, one of the most violent incidents in the mounting unrest that’s killed dozens of people.
title: Iran Probes Hospital Raid as Protest Crackdown Leaves 29 Dead

description: Donald Trump's rationale for decapitating Venezuela's government is fueling concerns among European officials that they could soon face an existential dilemma over Greenland. Trump has made it explicit that he needs to control Greenland for security purposes, citing a modern revival of the 19th-century Monroe Doctrine, which he dubbed the "Donroe Doctrine". Bloomberg Opinion's Marc Champion has been writing about this in his latest piece 'The Greenland Alarm Sounds. Europe Should Listen'. He joins Stephen Carroll and Valerie Tytel on Bloomberg Radio to discuss. (Source: Bloomberg)
title: Should Europe Be Worried By Trump's Greenland Demand?

author: Arne Delfs
description: German Chancellor Friedrich Merz described “certain sectors” of his country’s economy as being in “very critical” condition in a letter to lawmakers, adding that reviving growth will be his government’s top priority this year.
title: Merz Says Parts of German Economy in ‘Very Critical’ Condition

author: Raga Justin
description: George Conway, an attorney and prominent critic of President Donald Trump, on Tuesday launched his congressional campaign Tuesday with an ad focused on his adversarial relationship with the president.
title: Conway Kicks Off Campaign for NYC House Seat With Anti-Trump Ad

author: Soo-Hyang Choi
description: South Korean President Lee Jae Myung met with Chinese Premier Li Qiang and pledged deeper cooperation in talks that echoed his summit with President Xi Jinping as Seoul seeks a “full restoration” of bilateral ties.
title: South Korea’s Lee Seeks ‘Full Restoration’ of Ties With China

description:
Bloomberg Daybreak Europe is your essential morning viewing to stay ahead. Live from London, we set the agenda for your day, catching you up with overnight markets news from the US and Asia. And we'll tell you what matters for investors in Europe, giving you insight before trading begins.

On today's show, Denmark's Prime Minister claims the NATO alliance would end if the US were to attack Greenland. Mette Frederiksen says Donald Trump should be taken seriously when he says he wants Greenland - putting Danish officials on alert after the raid on Caracas over the weekend. 

Delcy Rodríguez was sworn in as acting president of Venezuela amid signs the unrest is unleashing a new wave of repression. 

Nicolás Maduro pleaded not guilty to drug charges in his first court appearance in the US.

Today's guests: Elisabeth Braw, Senior fellow at Atlantic Council (Source: Bloomberg)
title: Greenland on Alert After US Venezuela Move & Danish PM NATO Warning | 1/6/2026

author: Josh Xiao
description: China imposed controls on exports to Japan with any military use, intensifying a dispute between Asia’s top economies over remarks Japanese Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi made last year on Taiwan.
title: China Slaps Export Controls on Japan Military for Taiwan Remarks

description: European leaders and US officials aim to finalize an agreement on security guarantees that include the possibility of American boots on the ground in postwar Ukraine in a bid to ensure that any peace deal endures. French President Emmanuel Macron will host the Paris meeting. The US will be represented by President Donald Trump’s envoys Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner, according to people familiar with the matter. Bloomberg’s Greg Sullivan reports.
title: European, US Officials Set for Ukraine Talks in Paris

description: Danish Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen said that if US President Donald Trump were to attack Greenland, it would mean the end of the NATO alliance. Trump has long argued that the US must control Greenland to ensure its own security. Officials in Copenhagen have been alarmed by the US president’s insistence on taking control of the Danish island for security reasons following the raid on Caracas during which US forces arrested Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro. Bloomberg’s Sanne Wass reports.
title: Denmark Says a US Attack on Greenland Would Break NATO

author: Swati Pandey
description: Australia’s most populous state extended a temporary ban on protests and some other public assemblies for another 14 days, citing lingering public safety concerns after a terrorist attack at Bondi and heightened geopolitical tensions.
title: Australia State Extends Ban on Protests After Bondi Beach Attack

author: Sara Sjolin, Andrea Palasciano, Sanne Wass
description: Donald Trump’s rationale for decapitating Venezuela’s government is fueling concerns among European officials that they could soon face an existential dilemma over Greenland.
title: Trump’s Greenland Logic Spells Trouble for Europe and NATO

author: Patricia Garip, Ben Bartenstein, Eric Martin
description: As the US threatened Nicolás Maduro’s grip on power in recent months, a cadre of executives, lawyers and investors tied to the oil industry made their case to anyone who would listen — the Trump administration, congressional aides: His familiar No. 2 Delcy Rodríguez should fill his shoes in Venezuela.
title: Venezuela’s New Leader Is Who Global Oil Wanted All Along

author: Alex Wickham
description: Keir Starmer wanted to use the new year to reassure Britons he’s focused on worries at home. Instead, he was served up an immediate reminder of how much of his agenda is being set by Donald Trump in Washington.
title: Starmer’s New Year Reset Bid Gets Quickly Sidetracked by Trump

author: Pathom Sangwongwanich
description: Thailand’s Prime Minister Anutin Charnvirakul said his government is weighing possible responses after accusing Cambodian forces of firing mortar rounds in Thai territory and breaching a recent ceasefire.
title: Thailand Says Cambodia Breached Ceasefire, Weighs Next Steps

author: Matthew Brooker
description: Take a trip out on the London Underground’s Metropolitan Line and you soon find yourself passing through neighborhoods of semi-detached and detached houses with gardens, giving way on occasion to green fields. In Paris or Tokyo, you’d be far more likely to be looking out on apartment blocks of three to six stories. The preponderance of low-rise single-family homes close to train lines and within cities is what gives Britain’s landscape its distinctive character. It’s also a factor in one of the
title: Britain's Housing Crisis Has Seeds in the 1930s

description: US strikes, the capture of President Nicolas Maduro and the US intention to run the country — at least temporarily — mean Venezuela has a shot at restoring democracy and prosperity. Neither outcome is guaranteed. US President Donald Trump’s Jan. 3 news conference and remarks from Secretary of State Marco Rubio on Jan. 4 left many questions unanswered. Jimena Zuniga serves as Latin America Geoeconomics Analyst and Argentina Economist at Bloomberg Economics. She discusses what might happen next in the embattled South American nation with Carol Massar and Tim Stenovec on Bloomberg Businessweek Daily. (Source: Bloomberg)
title: Three Possible Paths for Venezuela After Maduro's Ouster

description: "Balance of Power: Late Edition" focuses on the intersection of politics and global business. On today's show, Mike Lawler, Republican Representative of New York, talks about President Trump's legal justifications for his actions against Venezuela and the ouster of President Nicolas Maduro, and Maggie Goodlander, Democratic Representative of New Hampshire, discusses the Maduro ouster and says the Trump administration has a lot of questions to answer about what comes next for Venezuela. (Source: Bloomberg)
title: World Braces for Impact Following US Ouster of Maduro | Balance of Power: 1/5/2026

author: Hadriana Lowenkron, Kate Sullivan
description: President Donald Trump asked Secretary of State Marco Rubio to lead the process to implement economic and political reforms in Venezuela and the US believes it is getting “full, complete and total” cooperation from the government in Caracas after the capture of Nicolas Maduro, White House senior adviser Stephen Miller said Monday.
title: Trump Asks Rubio to Lead Venezuela Overhaul After Maduro Arrest

description: Mike Lawler, Republican Representative of New York, joins Tyler Kendall and Joe Mathieu on 'Bloomberg: Balance of Power' to discuss the US ouster of Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro, saying President Donald Trump was legally justified with the military strike, and that he does not blame the administration for withholding information from Congress prior to the operation. (Source: Bloomberg)
title: President is Legally Justified in Military Strikes: Rep. Lawler
